title: On the Welfare (Ir)Relevance of Two-Stage Models

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In a two-stage model of choice a decision maker first shortlists a given menu and then applies her preferences. We show that a sizable class of these models run into significant issues in terms of identification of preferences (welfare-relevance) and thus cannot be used for welfare analysis. We classify these models by their revealed preference principles and expose the principle that we deem to be the root of their identification issue. Taking our analysis to an experimental data, we observe that half of the alternatives that are revealed preferred to another under rational choice are left revealed preferred to nothing for any member of this class of models. Furthermore, the welfare-relevance of the specific models established in the literature are much worse. The model with the highest welfare-relevance produces a revealed preference relation with the average density of $2 \%$ ( 1 out of 45 possible comparisons revealed), while rational choice does $63 \%$ ( 28 out of 45 possible comparisons). We argue that the issue is not an inherent feature of two-stage models, and rather lies in the approach with which the first stage is modeled in the literature.

## 1 Introduction

Models of bounded rationality have long been of interest as a way to accommodate "irrational" patterns. The standard approach of these models is to generalize rational choice model by adding degrees of freedom; i.e., new primitives of the model. Examples are adding shortlisting stages, reference points or perturbing the preference relations. However, enriching the set of primitives inevitably leads to potential identification problems due to the increased degrees of freedom. Intuitively then one could conjecture that such models would be weak in terms of identification power compared to rational choice. Recent papers in the literature (see Dardanoni et al. (2020) and Dardanoni et al. (2023)) acknowledge this and hence suggest considering population data instead, hinting to a drawback that such models impose a "richness" condition on the data "comprising a single individual's choices from a large number of different overlapping menus".

[^0]
[^0]:    *We would like to thank Yuta Inoue and Koji Shirai for providing the data used in this paper.
    ${ }^{\dagger}$ Department of Economics, University of Essex. e-mail: m.freer@essex.ac.uk
    $\ddagger$ ECARES, Université Libre de Bruxelles. e-mail: seyed.nosratabadi@ulb.be

Two-stage models constitute a large class of models of bounded rationality. In these models a decision maker (DM) first makes a shortlist from a given problem and then uses her preferences to choose the best alternative from the shortlisted ones. One particularly interesting observation that speaks to the identification problem in many of these models is that if the data set is consistent with rational choice, then one cannot identify preferences at all. ${ }^{1}$ This "inconsistency-dependency" is a rather paradoxical feature in that the models that are aimed to generalize rational choice can only be identified if observed choice is not rational.

In this paper, we follow the revealed preference tradition to better understand the issue of preference identification in two-stage models. This tradition speaks to establishing a proper mapping between the set of observables (choice) to the set of unobservables of the decision process. (preferences, cognitive constrains, etc.) Thus we try to find the common observational requirements these models impose to reveal preferences. we refer to these requirements as revealed preference principles (RP principles). In particular, we define these principles in terms of an alternative being revealed preferred to at least another (having a non-empty lower contour set).

The first principle we introduce is a stringent one called choice over pivots (CoP). A pivot is an alternative the removal of which alters choice. CoP implies that an alternative that is not at least chosen over a pivot in a data point, will have an empty lower contour set. For rational choice, in contrast, each choice observation is welfare-relevant: the chosen alternative is better than those that are available but not chosen. Four prominent twostage models follow CoP. These models are (i) limited attention (Masatlioglu et al. (2012)), (ii) limited consideration (Lleras et al. (2017)), (iii) rational shortlist method (Manzini and Mariotti (2007)), and (iv) transitive rational shortlist method (Au and Kawai (2011)).

The second RP principle is standard transitive closure (STC): if a data set does not help identifying any information about the lower contour set of an alternative, then adding more data where the alternative is not available at all can not help with the identification. That is, as in rational choice, the indirect revealed preference relation can only built upon an already non-empty direct revelation. This is a rather uncontroversial principle that intuitively should hold for almost any standard two-stage model. Indeed, in addition to the four models above, rational choice follows it as well. It turns out that, when combined with CoP, this new property exacerbates the observational burden on welfare analysis: an alternative now needs to be involved in a violation of the weak axiom of revealed preferences (WARP) to be have a non-empty lower contour set, where involvement means being chosen in the intersection of a WARP violation. ${ }^{2}$

We next introduce an even more stringent RP principle: choice over choice (CoC): an alternative that is not chosen over a chosen alternative has an empty lower contour set. To see why this property is more stringent than CoP, note that there are two type of pivots : chosen points and unchosen points. CoC immediately disregards the latter type of pivots for revealed preference purposes. All models except (iv) follow CoC. When combined with

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ This for example is the case for the models in Masatlioglu et al. (2012), Lleras et al. (2017), Manzini and Mariotti (2007), and Au and Kawai (2011) among many others.
    ${ }^{2}$ Many other two-stage models do run into this welfare-irrelevance result. Examples are Lleras et al. (2021), Inoue and Shirai (2022), Yildiz (2016), Kimya (2018), Geng and Özbay (2021), Horan (2016), and Geng (2022). For the sake of being concise we do not include them in our analysis.

STC, the extra observational burden becomes the following: for an alternative to have a non-empty lower contour set it has to be directly involved in a WARP violation - i.e., cause the WARP violation itself. ${ }^{3}$

The important point about our result is that the inconsistency-dependency feature is not an innate feature of a two-stage model, and rather due to the formulation of a typical twostage model in the literature. Take for example a model where DM shortlists with mechanics in the first stage unknown to the observer, but in a way that at least two alternatives are considered in the second stage. The intuition of this assumption is that DM faces a trade-off in the second stage. In such a model, welfare analysis can be done whether or not the data exhibits irrational patters. Since we argue that STC is a rather non-restrictive assumption, the underlying reason for identification issues are CoP and CoC. Indeed, a model with this size-dependent formulation of the first stage still satisfies STC, and thus moves beyond the inconsistency-dependent feature precisely because it violates CoP. Finally, our results also indicate that not all patterns of violations are welfare-relevant in these models. To be more precise, the violation of strong axiom of revealed preferences (SARP) are yet welfareirrelevant if they are not WARP violations. ${ }^{4}$

We complement our analysis by an experimental illustration. We first report welfareirrelevance results regarding our theoretical analysis based on $\mathbf{C o P}(\mathbf{C})$. We show that half of the alternatives that have non-empty lower contour sets under rational choice will be left with an empty lower contour set in any two-stage model that follows $\operatorname{CoP}(\mathbf{C})$ and STC. After providing the general analysis of the class of models, we then zoom in and provide the welfare-relevance of the specific two-stage models (i)-(iv). Using this specific models allows us to provide precise results on welfare-relevance by talking about the density of the revealed preference relation. That is, the number of comparisons revealed given a model normalized by the total number of comparisons existing in a complete and acyclic binary relation. This precise welfare-relevance measure is drastically lower for these specific models when compared to the general drop observed in the number of alternatives with non-empty lower contour sets. The best model is (iv) (the only non-CoC model in the list above) for which only $2 \%$ of preferences are revealed, while for rational choice $63 \%$ of comparisons are revealed. These results illustrate that, even in the class of two-stage models that follow CoP and STC, these specific models deliver minimal welfare-relevance.

Next, we investigate versions of these model where we force a CoP-violating assumption in order to see whether or not we can improve their welfare-relevant. For this objective, we consider amended versions of these models by assuming that DM (in addition to following the rules of the model) also always considers at least two alternatives. The amended versions, as discussed before, violate CoP and thus does not have to follow the inconsistency-dependent results. These models deliver two important results. First, the average density of revealed preferences relation rises to about $20 \%$ which is about a third of density for the rational choice. This is a rather significant increase and potentially sufficient in many applications given that we are dealing with two-stage models with an extra primitive. More importantly, this rise is almost the same regardless of the model (densities are in the range $17 \%$ to $21 \%$ ),

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ Note that neither CoP nor CoC implies irrational patters in choice. It is indeed combining it with STC that makes preference identification dependent on WARP violations. For a discussion, see section 3.
    ${ }^{4}$ That is, choice cycles of orders higher than two. It is worth noting that the dissection between the two types of violations is only possible if the data set is incomplete. For a discussion on this see Section 3.

hinting that the CoP-violating assumption (the size dependent formation) is by far more relevant for preference identification than the conditions imposed on the first stage of these model.

Our analysis assumes that the observer only has access to an incomplete (realistic) data set. The analysis of two-stage models given such data set has received attention recently. De Clippel and Rozen (2021) investigates the question of falsifiability of a variety of behavioral models (some of which are in our analysis as well) in such a setting. They provide a common way for testing the models; that is to see if an observed data set could be produced by a given model. Our question is instead on identifiability of preferences within these models.

As mentioned earlier, a simple way to break the inconsistency-dependent identification is to ensure that DM performs some comparisons after shortlisting. This idea has been used in the literature before, for example in Barseghyan et al. (2021) and Bajraj and Ülkü (2015). ${ }^{5}$ In addition, the consideration capacity model in Dardanoni et al. (2020) is reminiscent of the same principle.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents necessary definitions. Section 3 presents the theoretical results. Section 4 provides experimental illustration. Section 5 concludes. All proofs omitted in the text can be found in the Appendix.

# 2 Definitions 

Let $X$ be a finite universal set of alternatives. Let $\mathcal{B} \subseteq 2^{X}$ be a collection of choice problems with at least two alternatives $(|B| \geq 2$ for all $B \in \mathcal{B})$ where $2^{X}$ is the set of all the subsets of $X . \boldsymbol{c}: \mathcal{B} \rightarrow X$ is a choice function if $\boldsymbol{c}(B) \in B$. Thus a data set can be described by the pair $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Let $\boldsymbol{c}(\mathcal{B})=\bigcup_{B \in \mathcal{B}} \boldsymbol{c}(B)$ be the collection of all chosen points in the data set. A binary relation $\succ \subseteq X \times X$ is a strict preference relation if it is complete (any pair of alternatives is comparable), transitive ( $x \succ x^{\prime}$ and $x \succ x^{\prime}$ implies $x \succ x^{\prime \prime}$ for any $x, x^{\prime}, x^{\prime \prime} \in$ $X$ ), and asymmetric ( $x \succ x^{\prime}$ implies $x^{\prime} \not \succ x$ for any $x, x^{\prime} \in X$ ). By $\max (B, \succ)$ we mean the set of maximal elements of $\succ$ in $B$; that is, $\max (B, \succ)=\{x \in B: \nexists y \in B: y \succ x\}$.

Two-Stage Models In the first stage DM shortlists a given problem using a filter: a mapping $F: 2^{X} \rightarrow 2^{X}$ such that $F(B) \subseteq B$. We denote the set of all possible filters by $\mathfrak{F} . F(B)$ thus may be understood as the consideration set for the problem $B$. The second stage, without loss of generality, could be assumed to consist of applying a well-defined preference relation on what survives the first stage. ${ }^{6}$ Naturally we assume that, a priori, any

[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ The latter paper in particular introduces a two-stage model where DM picks the top two alternative based on a linear order in the first stage, and then applies another linear order (preference relation) in the second stage. Thus this model is slightly different from the size-dependent formulation we mentioned earlier because there more than two alternative may appear in the second stage.
    ${ }^{6}$ An elaboration may be needed here. In general one may impose a weaker requirement on the binary relation in the second stage. For example, Manzini and Mariotti (2007) only requires an asymmetric binary relation in the second stage. However, in order for the choice function to be well-defined (i.e., non-empty valued) one need to at the end impose acyclicity over the items that survive the first stage. This would mean that any two-stage model generates a well-defined choice function if and only if it makes uses of a strict linear order in the

preferences in the second stage are allowed for any $\mathcal{F}$. Consequently, the only distinguishing aspect of any given pair of models is their first stage; i.e., the collection of filters they allow. A two-stage model $\mathcal{F}$ thus is simply a subset of $\mathfrak{F}$. Rationalizability would then mean that one could find a filter in $\mathcal{F}$ and a preference relation to generate the observed data with.

Definition 1. A two-stage model of choice is a collection of filters; i.e., $\mathcal{F}$ is a two-stage model if and only if $\mathcal{F} \subseteq \mathfrak{F}$. A data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ is rationalizable with model $\mathcal{F}$ if there exist
(i) a filter $F \in \mathcal{F}$, and
(ii) a preference relation $\succ$,
such that

$$
\boldsymbol{c}(B)=\max (F(B), \succ)
$$

for every $B \in \mathcal{B} .^{7}$
The definition above is as general as possible. One can think of an extremely exclusive model such as $\mathcal{F}_{1}$ that only includes one filter, say the identity filter: $F(B)=B$ for all $B$; i.e., the classical rational choice. $\mathcal{F}_{2}$ could be another model that filters anything but $x_{1}$ out when $x_{1}$ is available, otherwise anything but $x_{2}$ is filtered out when $x_{2}$ is available, $\ldots$, otherwise anything but $x_{n}$ when $x_{n}$ is available, and where $X=\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$. Of course one can conceive a model $\mathcal{F}_{3}=\mathfrak{F}$; i.e., a model with no restriction on filter selection. At the same time, $\mathcal{F}_{4}=\mathcal{F}_{1} \cup \mathcal{F}_{2}$ is another model in this framework.

Revealed Preferences (RP) Let us next formalize the revealed preference relation. We need to introduce some additional notations first. Let

$$
\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})=\{(\succ, F) \text { that rationalize }(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})\}
$$

be the collection of all the instances of the model that rationalize the data set. For a rationalizable data set (i.e., $\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}) \neq \varnothing$ ), we can define the revealed preference relation as

$$
\succ^{*}=\bigcap_{(\succ, F) \in \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})} \succ
$$

Also let $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))$ be the the set of alternatives revealed inferior to $x$ given the data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ according to $\succ^{*}$; that is, the lower contour set of $x$.

The last notation is the following. Consider a two-stage model where DM makes at least one comparison in the second stage; that is, the filters of size of at least two. When we observe the data point $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)=\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y, z\}=x$ what can we infer about preferences? We would know that $x \succ^{*} y$ or $x \succ^{*} z$. These latter two pieces of information impose a
second stage. That is assuming second stage rationality is with no restriction on the explanatory power of the model. For a similar classification of two-stage models see Tyson (2013).
${ }^{7}$ Note that by definition a filter is a mapping defined on $2^{X}$. Thus, our definition of rationalizability entails the existence of an extension of any incomplete data set to a complete one consistent with the model. To see the importance of the existence of such an extension, and the fact that is not guaranteed, see De Clippel and Rozen (2021).

"restriction" on the lower contour set of $x$, absent of extra observation, they nonetheless do not enrich RP; that is, $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing$. The restrictions could be insightful with more data though. For example, if we collected another data point in the form of $\boldsymbol{c}\{x, z\}=z$, then we would know that $z \succ^{*} x$, and using the or-logic that $x \succ^{*} y$. This indicates the important of the or-logic in performing RP in two-stage models. In order to contain these information in our analysis then we use the notation $\mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))$ to be the set of all restrictions on the lower contour set of $x$. In our example, we have $\mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}\left(x \mid\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)\right)=\left\{\left(x \succ^{*} y\right.\right.$ or $\left.\left.x \succ^{*} z\right)\right\}^{89}$

# 2.1 Prominent Two-Stage Models 

- Limited Attention (LA, see Masatlioglu et al., 2012)

Attention Filters: Filters are insensitive to removal of filtered alternatives.

$$
F \in \mathcal{F} \text { if and only if } F(B)=F(B \backslash\{x\}) \text { if } x \notin F(B)
$$

- Limited Consideration (LC, see Lleras et al., 2017)

Competition Filters: The set of filtered alternatives may only shrink if the choice problem expands:

$$
F \in \mathcal{F} \text { if and only if } F(B) \cap B^{\prime} \subseteq F\left(B^{\prime}\right) \text { if } B^{\prime} \subseteq B
$$

- Rational Shortlist Method (RSM, see Manzini and Mariotti, 2007)

Asymmetric Binary Filter: Irrespective of the choice problem, if $x$ filters $y$ out, then $y$ does not filter $x$ out. Formally, there is an asymmetric binary relation $\succ_{0}$ the maximal elements of which survive the first stage.

$$
F \in \mathcal{F} \text { if and only if } F(B)=\max \left(B, \succ_{0}\right)
$$

- Transitive Rational Shortlist Method (TRSM, see Au and Kawai, 2011)

Asymmetric and Transitive Binary Filter: In addition to asymmetry, and again irrespective of the choice problem, if $x$ filters $y$ out and $y$ filters $z$ out, then $x$ filters $z$ out. Formally, there is a asymmetric and transitive binary relation $\succ_{0}$ that characterizes the filter:

$$
F \in \mathcal{F} \text { if and only if } F(B)=\max \left(\succ_{0}, B\right)
$$

Note that, RSM is nested in LC (but not in LA). TRSM is of course nested in RSM and thus in LC, but it has been shown that it is also in both LA. These relationships are interesting to consider later where we quantify the welfare-relevance of these models. ${ }^{10}$

For example, $\left(x \succ^{*} y\right.$ or $\left.z \succ^{*} t\right)$ and $\left(x \succ^{*} y\right.$ or $\left.z \succ^{*} x\right)$ are also valid restrictions for $x$ and thus belong to $\mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}\left(x \mid\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)\right)$. A second note is that or-logic could also appear in some of the prominent two-stage models in the literature. See De Clippel and Rozen (2021) for a comprehensive discussion on this matter.

Unless needed though, we omit these extra arguments in order to keep the flow of the writing.

# 3 Welfare (Ir)Relevance 

In this section we provide a set of fundamentals of two-stage models that should hint at their unimpressive identifiability (of preferences). These fundamentals will speak to the revealed preference principles of a model - i.e. the observational requirements for preference identification - instead of the "mechanics" of its filters. ${ }^{11}$ Let us start with some well-known concepts. Let $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ be a data set.
i. A WARP violation is a pair $\left(B_{1}, B_{2}\right): B_{i} \in \mathcal{B}$ such that $\boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{1}\right) \neq \boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{2}\right), \boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{1}\right), \boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{2}\right) \in$ $B_{1} \cap B_{2}$, and
ii. a SARP violation is a tuple $\left(B_{1}, B_{2}, \ldots, B_{n}\right): B_{i} \in \mathcal{B}$ such that $\boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{i}\right) \neq \boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{j}\right)$ for any $i \neq j, \boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{i}\right) \in B_{i+1}$ for every $i \leq n-1$ and $\boldsymbol{c}\left(B_{n}\right) \in B_{1}$, and
iii. a pure SARP violation is a SARP violation that is not a WARP violation.

Next, we introduce a fundamental notion that repeatedly appears in the literature of twostage models and plays a critical role in our analysis; i.e., pivots.

Definition 2. We call $p \in X$ a pivot in $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ if there exists $S \in X$ such that $\boldsymbol{c}(S) \neq \boldsymbol{c}(S-p)$ in all the choice functions generated by all the rationalization of $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. We denote the set of all pivot in the data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ by $\operatorname{piv}(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$.

Hence, a pivot is an alternative removal of which causes a change in DM's choice. Note that if a data set is consistent with rational choice model then the only pivots are chosen alternatives; that is, $\boldsymbol{c}(\mathcal{B}) .{ }^{12}$ We refer to this kind of pivot as Type 1. If rationality is violated, we could have unchosen alternatives that are pivots. For example, take the choice pattern $\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y\}=y$ and $\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y, z\}=x$ where removing $z$ changes DM's choice. We refer to such pivots as Type 2. ${ }^{13}$

### 3.1 Choice over Pivots

The key insight into the importance of pivots is the following: the removal of a pivot alters the consideration set irrespective of the two-stage model (that is, for all $\mathcal{F}$ in Definition 1). The reason is that the different choice made in the new set (after removal) and the original

(2013), Yildiz (2016), Kimya (2018), Geng and Özbay (2021), Horan (2016), and Geng (2022). Our analysis in the next section also implies to these models.

For a comprehensive discussion on the distinction between the two approaches see Manzini and Mariotti (2014).

set can not be rationalized with the same consideration set - that is, if removal of $t$ alters choice in $B$, then $F(B) \neq F(B-t)$. However, if the removal of an alternative does not alter the choice in a given problem, then a construction where the consideration set before and after is unchanged seems both straightforward and intuitive. This particular rationalization of course could only be the case if the removed alternative was not considered before the change; that is, alternatives that are not pivots may be assumed out of consideration sets. The latter assertion is indeed the link that connects various two-stage models. This common link, in turn, imposes a necessary condition on the revealed preference relation. The standard revealed preference approach maps the set of unobservables (preferences along with other decision elements) to the observed choice patterns. It is natural in such an approach that for an alternative that is never chosen to be not revealed better than any other. ${ }^{14}$ On the other hand, the argument above tells us that if an alternative is considered is some choice problem that it is a pivot. Consequently, a necessary condition for an alternative to be revealed superior to another is for it to be chosen over a pivot. This principle is formalized next.

Choice over Pivots (CoP). If $x$ is not chosen over a pivot in a data set, then there are no restrictions on the lower contour set of $x$ given that data set; that is,
$\forall(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}), \forall x$, if $\nexists y \in \operatorname{pi} v(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ and $B \in \mathcal{B}$ such that $x=\boldsymbol{c}(B)$ and $y \in B$, then $\mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=$ $\varnothing$.

Before proceeding further let us make two important remarks about CoP. First, this RP principle is quite demanding than compared to the RP principle under rational choice. For an alternative to have non-empty lower contour set it is (necessary and) sufficient for this alternative to be chosen in some problem. Such principle is indeed not compatible with CoP. In the two-stage world in which these models operate, to infer that $x$ is better than "something", it is necessary to observe two patterns: (i) a data point that shows $x$ is chosen where $y$ is available, and (ii) a pair of data points that indicates $y$ is a pivot. Moreover, CoP is not a sufficient condition for RP. The second point is that one can easily contemplate a reasonable two-stage models that violates CoP. Assume that DM always has at least two alternatives in her consideration set. This model obviously violates CoP since any observation on a doubleton (such as $\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y\}=x$ ) in isolation allows us to infer DM's preferences over the pair. $(x \succ y)$

While CoP is rather demanding, the second RP principle that we propose is instead uncontroversial and is satisfied by a wide variety of two-stage models. Assume that the observer uses the two-stage model $\mathcal{F}$ and infers $x \succ y$ given the data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. If she wants to know more about $x$, she may of course collect more data where $x$ is present. Nonetheless, she could also benefit from a data that does not contain $x$. This is because such data may help her infer $y \succ z$, and thus indirectly that $x \succ z$ by taking the transitive closure of the revealed preference relation. Needless to say, it seems natural that the second channel (indirect preferences) could only work if the initial data set tells us something about the lower contour set of $x$; that is indirect revelation may only built on an restrictions in the form of direct revelation.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{14}$ This is standard in the sense that it also holds true under rational choice.

Standard Transitive Closure (STC). If a data set does put any restriction on the lower contour set of $x$, then adding more data where $x$ is not available at all does not put any restrictions on the lower contour set of $x$; that is,

$$
\text { if } \mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}\left(x \mid\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)\right)=\varnothing \text {, and } x \notin \bigcup \mathcal{B}_{2} \text {, then } \mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}\left(x \mid\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right) \cup\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)\right)=\varnothing
$$

Note that if a data set does not put any or-restrictions on the set of inferiors to an alternative $\left(\mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing\right)$, then the lower contour set of $x$ will be empty. $(L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing)$ The reverse is obviously not true. An incipient intuitive inquiry about the principle above hence may be that whether it could be stronger. That is, doesn't it make sense that the extra data where $x$ is not present should not help identifying an alternative inferior to $x$ also in the case where the initial data did not reveal anything inferior to it?- that is, can we replace $\mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}$ with $L$ in the expression of this principle?

This turns out to be false. To see this take the model where DM shortlists a minimum of two alternatives. Our initial data point is $\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y, z\}=x$ which tells us that $x \succ^{*} y$ or $z \succ^{*} t$. Note that given this data we cannot pin down anything inferior to $x$ yet since there is a representation in which $x$ is ranked below $y$ and one where it is below $z$; i.e., $L(x)=\varnothing$. However, we can collect extra data where $x$ is not present, namely $\boldsymbol{c}\{y, z\}=y$ which indicates $y \succ^{*} z$. Now there are two possibilities. If $x$ is better than $y$ based on the initial data, then transitivity tells use that it is also better than $z$. In the other possibility $x$ is again better than $z$. Thus, $x$ is revealed better than $z$ for sure, even though the extra data did not contain $x$ at all. This example thus once again points to the relevance of the partial RP information produced by a model through or-logic. ${ }^{15}$

To further buttress that STC is much less less restrictive than CoP, recall that the two models we argued to violate CoP are rational choice and model where DM always considers at least two alternatives. Both these models satisfy STC. Indeed it seems hard to think of a "standard" two-stage model that violates STC. For example, take the model $\mathcal{F}=\mathfrak{F}$ where there is no restriction on the filter selection. In this model, we can always rationalized the data by "filtering anything but the choice out". That is, there is no welfare content in this model, and thus STC is obviously satisfied. It also can be shown that the two-stage models listed in Section 2.1 follow STC. Moreover, these models satisfy CoP.

# Remark 1. LA, LC, RSM, and TRSM follow CoP and STC. ${ }^{16}$ 

Therefore, these four models are members of a class of models defined by the two RP principles. Recall that any model in this family faces the observational burden due to CoP: to identify an alternative inferior to $x$, we would require that (i) $x$ to be chosen over an alterative and (ii) the removal of that alternative to also alter choice is some instance. It turns out indeed that, when combined with STC, the observational burden becomes more more severe: instances where (i) and (ii) occur need to be closely related.

Theorem 1. Assume $\mathcal{F}$ follows $\boldsymbol{C o P}$ and $\boldsymbol{S T C}$. If $x$ is not involved in a WARP violation - that is, if there does not exit $T, S, Q \in \mathcal{B}$ with $x \in T \cap S \cap Q$, and $Q \cap(S \backslash\{x\}) \neq \varnothing$ or $Q \cap(T \backslash\{x\}) \neq \varnothing$, such that
i. $(T, S)$ is a WARP violation,
ii. $\boldsymbol{c}(Q)=x$,
then it is not revealed preferred to any other alternative; that is, $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing$.

Theorem 1 shows that for an alternative to have non-empty lower contour set it is no sufficient to be chosen over a pivot and it is further required to be involved in a WARP violation. Figure 4 a helps us to see this further requirement in three layers. First note that being chosen over pivots does not imply violations of rationality. An instance is illustrated on Figure 1a, where $x$ is chosen over the pivot $y$, while there are no violations of rational choice. Theorem 1 implies that nothing can be inferred about the lower contour set of $x$. More generally, if there are no violations of rationality in a data set, then the same reasoning holds for any alternative. Theorem 1 thus implies rather a known feature of these models: if the data set is consistent with standard rationality (has no SARP violations), then there is no preferences revealed.

Corollary 1. Assume $\mathcal{F}$ satisfies $\boldsymbol{C o P}$ and $\boldsymbol{S T C}$. If that data set is rational - i.e., no SARP violations - then $\mathcal{F}$ is welfare-irrelevant; that is, $\succ^{*}=\varnothing .{ }^{17}$

While known, Corollary 1 may appear paradoxical. Identification in these models is linked to the irrational patterns they are intended to explain! Importantly, let us not that this is not an innate feature of two-stage models. Take, once again, the example of a DM who always considers at least two alternatives. Abstract away from any consistency conditions on filter formation for a moment. We are able to directly infer her preferences in doubletons. In addition, when the decision problem has more than two alternatives, we would get partial information in the form of the or-logic which, in combination with direct information, could further enrich identification. This we can do whether or not the data set exhibits violations of rationality.

The second layer of observational burden implied by Theorem 1 is illustrated in Figure 1b. Here $x$ is chosen over a pivot $y$. No there is a violation of rational choice: $x$ is chosen over $y$, which, in turn, is chosen over $z$, which is then chosen over $x$. This a pure SARP violation though, and, hence, $x$ is not involved in a WARP violation. According to Theorem 1 we are yet again unable to say anything about the lower contour set of $x$.

Corollary 2. Assume $\mathcal{F}$ satisfies $\boldsymbol{C o P}$ and $\boldsymbol{S T C}$. If the set of violations in the data set only consists of pure SARP violations, then $\mathcal{F}$ is welfare-irrelevant; that is, $\succ^{*}=\varnothing$.

It is important to note that Corollary 2 is only relevant if the data set is incomplete. It is a well-known (also straightforward to observe) that if a data set in hand is complete, then any SARP violation in a section of the data will inevitably create a WARP violation somewhere else.

Finally, Figure 1c presents a case where $x$ is chosen over a pivot, and that there is a case of WARP violation (between the choice problems in gray and orange). However, $x$ is not present in the intersection of this violation, and thus, not involved in it. Once again Theorem 1 implies that the lower contour set of $x$ is an empty set.

# 3.2 Choice over Choice 

Recall that there are two types of pivots: (i) the chosen ones, and (ii) the unchosen ones the removal of which alters choice. While CoP is a necessary condition for all four models listed we listed before, it turns out that three of them - LA, LC, and RSM - impose an even tighter necessary condition for preference identification. For these models being chosen over a Type 2 pivot does not allow to draw any inference about the non-emptiness of the lower contour sets.

Choice over Choice (CoC). If $x$ is not chosen over a chosen alternative in a data set, then there are no restrictions on the lower contour set of $x$ given that data set; that is,

$$
\forall(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}), \forall x \text { if } \nexists B \in \mathcal{B}, y \in \boldsymbol{c}(\mathcal{B}) \text { such that } x=\boldsymbol{c}(B) \text { and } y \in B, \text { then } \mathcal{R}^{\downarrow}(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{17}$ While we can use Theorem 1, another simple argument is useful. It is easy to check that a strict linear order satisfies the filter conditions of all these models. Thus, when fed a rational pattern we can attribute the pattern completely to the filter - anything but the choice is filtered out - and thus use any preference in the second stage.

Remark 2. LA, LC, and RSM follow CoC.
Imposing a tighter necessary condition on revealed preferences through CoC, when combined with STC, further exacerbates the observational burden established in Theorem 2. In order to make sure that a given alternative has a non-empty lower contour set, the alternative needs to itself cause a WARP violation (or be directly involved in a WARP violation).
Theorem 2. Assume $\mathcal{F}$ follows $\boldsymbol{C o C}$ and $\boldsymbol{S T C}$. If $x$ is not directly involved in a WARP violation in $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$ - that is, if there does not exist $S, T \in \mathcal{B}$ such that $x=\boldsymbol{c}(S), S \cap$ $T \ni x, \boldsymbol{c}(T)$, and $x \neq \boldsymbol{c}(T)$ - then $x$ is not revealed preferred to any alternatives; that is, $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing$.

Note that if $x$ is directly involved in a WARP violation, then it is involved in a WARP violation. Figure 2 visually contrasts these two notions. Under CoC, in the best case, we can make inference about non-emptiness of lower contour sets for the points that are directly involved in a WARP violation; i.e., two points in total. Under CoP however a single WARP violation could contribute to identification for more alternatives as long as they are chosen in the intersection of this violation. Hence, an important takeaway from Theorems 1 and 2 is that TRSM has a theoretical potential to perform better than the other three models.

CoC will have a stronger welfare-irrelevance implication as long as pure SARP violations are concerned: any alternative that is only involved in pure SARP violation - that is the choice cycles it is a part of are always of an order higher than two - will have nothing revealed inferior to it, despite the data set exhibiting WARP violations. This is the content of the next corollary with which we conclude this section.
Corollary 3. Assume that $\mathcal{F}$ satisfies $\boldsymbol{C o C}$ and $\boldsymbol{S T C}$. If $x$ is only involved in a pure SARP violation, then $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c}))=\varnothing$.

# 4.1 General Welfare-Relevance: Theorems 1 and 2 

Recall that Theorems 1 and 2 can help us determine the number of alternatives with nonempty lower contour sets, that is number of alternatives that are revealed preferred to some other. To put things in perspective, we use the equivalent indicator for the benchmark model of rational choice where it will be equal to the total number of distinct chosen alternatives, since any chosen alternative is revealed preferred to another in that model. ${ }^{19}$ Next, we have the family of two-stage model that follow CoP and STC. By Theorem 1, the indicator here is the number of those alternatives that are involved in a WARP violation. Finally, under Theorem 2, the indicator for the two-stage models following CoC and STC is the number of alternatives that are directly involved in a WARP violation.

# 4.2 Welfare-Relevance: LA, LC, RSM, and TRSM 

As discussed in the previous section, these models follow CoP (and CoC). We also intuitively argued why this RP principles impose a strong restriction on welfare-analysis. Here, we intend to quantify the extent of this restriction. In doing so, we make use of the model discussed several times previously: the model that only is concerned with the size of the consideration sets, and not with any consistency conditions. We denote to this model by $\mathrm{NC}_{\mathrm{k}}$ (NC for No-Consistency) where $k$ is the minimum size of the consideration set. Note that, for $\mathrm{NC}_{1}$ is a model where anything goes through; i.e., DM could be interpreted as if she filters anything but the chosen alternative out. Thus this model yet follows CoP. Importantly, on the other hand $\mathrm{NC}_{2}$ violates CoP (and thus CoC). Hence, is a good candidate to quantify the restrictive nature of these properties. We then amend this condition to the aforementioned models in order to see how much extra relevance can be brought to a particular theory by a single increment on $k$. Hence, for each of the four models and $\mathrm{NC}_{\mathrm{k}}$ we have two versions: (1) $k=1$ that is original theory, and (2) $k=2$ that is the amended theory assuming that subject makes at least one comparison before choosing.

Descriptive Power We start our analysis by evaluating the descriptive power of these models (both original and amended). That is, we would like to observe to which extent the observed data is consistent with a given model. The basic indicator here would be the pass rate: the share of subjects who pass the revealed preference test for the corresponding theory (and thus deemed as consistent). However, different theories would allow for different scope of permissible behaviors. Thus, the less restriction a model imposes (for example $\mathrm{NC}_{k}$, LA, LC relative to RSM and TRSM that are nested in LC), the higher its pass rate would be. To correct for this disparity, we also consider the Predictive Success Index (PSI) introduced by Selten (1991); Beatty and Crawford (2011). The goal behind PSI is to correct for potential false positives. In order to do so, we generate 1000 subjects who take random decisions at every round. A false positive then is such a random behavior whenever it is consistent with a given model. Normalizing the pass rates, PSI subtracts the pass rates of random subjects from that of real subjects. This index might take values between -1 and 1 , where $\mathrm{PSI}=-1$ means that every random subject is consistent with the theory while none of the real ones are. On the other hand $\mathrm{PSI}=1$ implies that while every real subject has passed the test, and none of the random ones did.

Figure 5 presents the results of the descriptive power measured as instructed above. The top panel (Figure 5a shows the raw pass rates for the models of interest. The dashed line presents the pass rate for the rational choice. White bars present the pass rates for the model in the original formulation, while gray bars show the pass rates for amend version (at least one comparison in the second stage). Let us start by noting that all models show the pass rates that are significantly above those for rational choice ( $33 \%$ for rational choice, while the lowest among the two-stage models is TRSM $\times k=2$ that is $58 \%$ ). This is of course expected as all these two-stage models generalize rational choice. A couple more interesting observations are the followings. LC and LA do not create significant drops in pass rates. More

Welfare-Relevance Next we proceed to analyze the welfare-relevance of these model by analyzing the density of the revealed preference relation they produce. By density we mean the number of the revealed comparisons inferred from a model divided by the number of comparisons that would have been present in the complete preference relation ( 45 in our data since there are 10 alternatives). Figure 6 presents the results for the models of interest.

The dashed line presents the density for rational choice. White bars present the density for the original version, while gray bars correspond to the amended version. It is important not note that we only compute densities for the subjects who are consistent with given model.

As expected, rational choice is quite efficient in revealing preferences, delivering the density of about 0.62 . However, looking at the original version of the four models we do not observe any notable revelation of preferences. For these models the density does not exceed .02 which is effectively negligible (less than one comparison per subject passing the model). Interestingly, there is no significant difference between RSM (following CoC) and TRSM (following CoP). An interpretation is that, while Theorems 1 and 2 open an extra potential channel for welfare-relevance (chosen over Type 2 pivots), TRSM does not appear to be taking advantage of the channel in any effective manner.

Finally, this figure showcases the relative importance of the ad-hoc amendment on the size of the consideration set in welfare-relevance relative to the consistency conditions imposed by each model. While the original models are equally ineffective, there is significant jump in the density from almost zero to about $.20(0.18-.22$ range) upon imposing the amendment. Interestingly, the intensity of the jump seems to be the same across the models, including NC. Hence, the major source of identification brought to these models appears to be the amendment not their consistency conditions. This practice indicates that the specific models we discussed seem to rank quite low in term of welfare-relevance in the class of models that follow these RP principles.

# 5 Conclusion 

In a two-stage model DM first makes a shortlist from a given choice problem and then applies her preferences to make a choice. Following the seminal paper of Manzini and Mariotti (2007), many models have been proposed, differing on what the right formulation of the first stage should be. Prominent examples include but not limited to Masatlioglu et al. (2012), Lleras et al. (2017), and Au and Kawai (2011). We show that all these models run into serious identification issues by quantifying the density of preference relations revealed. In the best case one can only infer $2 \%$ of all possible comparisons, while rational choice allows revealing $63 \%$ of all possible comparisons.

We theoretically trace the underlying reasons for this "welfare-irrelevance". A key notion is pivots - alternatives removal of which leads to changing the choice. These models, along with their counterparts in the literature, all operate on revealed preference principle that we refer to as choice over pivots: CoP: one can not identify the set of inferiors to an alternative that is not chosen over a pivot. Such an obviously restrictive revealed preference principle is not innate to two-stage models. It is rather an implication of the fact that these models insist on specifying particular mechanics of the first stage. Upon making sensible but rather ad-hoc assumptions (such as on the minimum size of the consideration set), two-stage models would violate CoP.

Our experimental analysis confirms CoP to be the source of welfare-irrelevance of these models. While these models in the original version are almost completely ineffective in revealing preferences (up to $2 \%$ ), they all significantly benefit from setting the minimum size of the consideration set equal to two. (about 20\%) There are two important aspect of our

analysis of the data. First, imposing the minimal restriction on the size of the consideration set has almost no negative effect on the descriptive power irrespective of the model. Second, the boost in welfare-relevance is of the same magnitude regardless of the model which is amended by this CoP-violating assumption. Our analysis overall suggests that the existing two-stage models can benefit from contextually proper but yet ad-hoc assumptions on the way consideration sets are formed a lot more than specifying the "right" mechanics of the first stage.

# A Proofs
## A. 1 Proof of Theorem 1

Take a given data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Also take an arbitrary $x$. If $x$ is never chosen in the data, then CoP gives us the desired result. So assume that $x$ is chosen somewhere. Assume that $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})) \neq \varnothing$. We show that $x$ is involved in a WARP violation. Partition the data set in three parts. (i): $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)$ which consists of those problems where $x$ is chosen, (ii) $\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)$ of those where $x$ is present but not chosen, and (iii) those where $x$ is not present. STC implies that if the observer can not draw any conclusion (infer any restrictions) from the first two partitions about the set of inferiors of a given alternative $x$, then she will not be able to do better by adding the third. That is, she has to infer some restrictions from $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right) \cup\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)$. But this would mean that she would need to see $x$ being chosen over a pivot in $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right) \cup\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)$. Let $Q$ be this choice problem and $t$ be the pivot in that problem. Thus, $t \in Q$ and $x=\boldsymbol{c}(Q)$. Given that $t$ is a pivot, there should be problems $S, T \in \mathcal{B}_{2}$ (by construction) such that $T=S-t$ and $\boldsymbol{c}(T) \neq \boldsymbol{c}(S)$. Recall that pivot can be either chosen or unchosen alternative.
Case 1: $t=\boldsymbol{c}(T)$. Since, $T \in \mathcal{B}_{2}$ we know that $x \in T$. Thus, $t, x \in T \cap Q$ and $t=\boldsymbol{c}(T) \neq$ $\boldsymbol{c}(Q)=x$. Thus, $x$ is (directly) involved in WARP violation.
Case 2: $t \neq \boldsymbol{c}(T)$. Then $\boldsymbol{c}(S) \in T$ and Thus, we have $\boldsymbol{c}(T), \boldsymbol{c}(S) \in S \cap T$ and $\boldsymbol{c}(S) \neq \boldsymbol{c}(T)$. Thus, $(T, S)$ constitute a WARP violation. Moreover, by construction $x \in T \cap S \cap Q$. Thus, we conclude that it is involved in a WARP violation.

## A. 2 Proof of Theorem 2

The proof here is akin to that of Theorem 1. Take a given data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Also take an arbitrary $x$. If $x$ is never chosen in the data, then CoC gives us the desired result. So assume that $x$ is chosen somewhere. Assume that $L(x \mid(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})) \neq \varnothing$. We show that $x$ is involved in a WARP violation. Partition the data set in three parts. (i): $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)$ which consists of those problems where $x$ is chosen, (ii) $\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)$ of those where $x$ is present but not chosen, and (iii) those where $x$ is not present. STC implies that if the observer can not draw any conclusion (infer any restrictions) from the first two partitions about the set of inferiors of a given alternative $x$, then she will not be able to do better by adding the third. That is, she has to infer some restrictions from $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right) \cup\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)$. Recall that by construction for every $T \in \mathcal{B}_{1}$ the chosen alternative is $x$. Hence, for $x$ to be chosen over another chosen alternative (as implied by CoC) there should be $y \in T$. Moreover, we can conclude that $y=\boldsymbol{c}(S)$ for $S \in \mathcal{B}_{2}$. However, by construction we know that $x \in S$ since $S \in \mathcal{B}_{2}$. Thus, we have $S, T \in \mathcal{B}_{1} \cup \mathcal{B}_{2}$ such that $x, y \in S \cap T$, while $\boldsymbol{c}(T)=x$ and $\boldsymbol{c}(S)=y$. That is, $x$ needs to be directly involved in a WARP violation.

## A. 3 Proof of Remarks 1 and 2

Proof. CoP. For LA, LC, and RSM we instead show that CoC is satisfied, and thus address the proof of Remark 2 as well.

LA. Take a data set that is realizable with LA. Following the argument in De Clippel and Rozen (2021) we know that there exists $\succ$ that satisfies the following set of restrictions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { for all } S, T \in \mathcal{B} \text { with } \boldsymbol{c}(S) \neq \boldsymbol{c}(T) \text { and } \boldsymbol{c}(S), \boldsymbol{c}(T) \in S \cap T: \\
& \boldsymbol{c}(S) \succ z \text { for some } z \in S \backslash T \text { or } \boldsymbol{c}(T) \succ z \text { for some } z \in T \backslash S
\end{aligned}
$$

Now take $x$ that is not chosen over a chosen alternative in the data set. Note that this means there are not restriction of the above form on the lower contour set of $x$ under $\succ^{*}$.

LC. Akin to the line of reasoning before and following a result in De Clippel and Rozen (2021), this time the set of restrictions are of the form

$$
\boldsymbol{c}(S) \succ \boldsymbol{c}(T) \text { whenever } \boldsymbol{c}(S) \neq \boldsymbol{c}(T) \in S \subset T
$$

Yet, again it follows that if $x$ is not chosen over a choice alternative, there are no restrictions on the lower contour set of $x$ under $\succ^{*}$.

RSM. Let $\left(\succ_{1}, \succ_{2}\right)$ RSM-rationalize the data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Fix $x$, and Let $A=\{t \neq x$ : $\exists B \in \mathcal{B}: x, t \in B, x=\boldsymbol{c}(B)\}$. This would directly imply that $t \succ_{1} x$ does not hold for any $t \in A$. Let $\succ_{1}^{\prime}=\succ_{1} \cup\{(x, t): t \in A\}$. It follows that $\succ_{1}^{\prime}$ is asymmetric. Next, let $\succ_{2}^{\prime}$ be a reordering of $\succ_{2}$ where we move $x$ to from its original rank (wherever) to the bottom of the order. Clearly $\left(\succ_{1}^{\prime}, \succ_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ is a RSM. We show that $\left(\succ_{1}^{\prime}, \succ_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ produces the same choice function on the choice problems. Call this choice function $\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}$. Starting with the $B$ where $x$ is chosen, note that $\succ_{1}^{\prime}$ filters anything but $x$ out. Thus $\boldsymbol{c}(B)=\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}(B)$ Going to the $B$ where $x$ is available, but not chosen, note that a choice in such a problem, say $y$, does not belong to $A$; that $x \succ^{\prime} y$ does not hold. This implies that neither of the changes implemented has an effect on choice in these problems and thus $\boldsymbol{c}(B)=\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}(B)$. Lastly, consider $B$ where $x$ is not present. We have only made changes to $x$. Thus, it directly follows that $\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}(B)=\boldsymbol{c}(B)$. Therefore, $\left(\succ_{1}^{\prime}, \succ_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ is a RSM-rationalization of $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Since $x=\operatorname{argmin} \succ_{2}^{\prime}$, it follows that no restriction is imposed on the lower contour set of $x$.

TRSM. We first prove the following claim.
Claim, If an alternative $p$ is not a pivot in the data, then there is always a TRSMrepresentation $\left(\succ_{1}^{\prime \prime}, \succ_{2}\right)$ where there are no $q$ such that $p \succ_{1}^{\prime \prime} q$.

To see this claim, take $\left(\succ_{1}, \succ_{2}\right)$ as a representation where the non-pivot alternative $p$ satisfies $p \succ_{1} q \in Q$. Let $\succ_{1}^{\prime}$ be a binary relation where we remove all of these latter cases. Note that $\succ_{1}^{\prime}$ remains both asymmetric and transitive. Clearly $\left(\succ_{1}^{\prime}, \succ_{2}\right)$ generates a TRSM rationalizable data set. We show that this generated data set matches the observed choices. For those problems where $p$ is not available, there is not argument needed. So take those where $p$ is available, and note that, since it is not a pivot it is not the choice in such problems. Next, since we shrunk the filter the consideration set in such sets may expand. So take $x$ that was not considered before the change and now it is considered; that is, $t \succ_{1} x$ and there is no comparison between the two in $\succ_{1}^{\prime}$. Since $p$ was not a pivot, even if removing it added $x$ to the consideration set before the change the choice would have remained the same. This means the choice alternative before removal is preferred to $x$. Thus, after the change and when $x$ is put back in the consideration set, the choice in the problem remains the same. So we have shown that $\left(\succ_{1}^{\prime}, \succ_{2}\right)$ also rationalizes the data set.

Having proved the claim above, the rest of the argument is similar to that of RSM. Let $\left(>_{1}\right.$ $\left.)>_{2}\right)$ TRSM-rationalize the data set $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Based on the claim above, let $\left(>_{1}^{*},>_{2}\right)$ another TRSM-rationalization where none of the pivots are ranked above any other alternatives according to $\succ_{1}^{*}$. Fix $x$, and Let $A=\{t \neq x: \exists B \in \mathcal{B}: x, t \in B, x=\boldsymbol{c}(B)\}$. Assume that $t \notin \operatorname{piv}(\mathcal{B})$ for all $t \in A$. This would mean that there are also not chosen any where and thus $t \nsucc_{1}^{*} x$ for all $t$ in $A$. We need to show there are no restriction on the lower contour set of $x$ under $>_{2}$. Let $\succ_{1}^{\prime}=>_{1}^{*} \cup\{(x, t): t \in A\}$. Since $t \nsucc_{1}^{*} x$, it follows that $>_{1}^{\prime}$ is asymmetric. Since $t$ are not ranked above any other alternative in $>_{1}^{*}$ then $>_{1}^{\prime}$ is also transitive. Next, let $\succ_{2}^{\prime}$ be a reordering of $>_{2}$ where we move $x$ to from its original rank (wherever) to the bottom of the order. Clearly $\left(>_{1}^{\prime},>_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ is a TRSM. We show that $\left(>_{1}^{\prime},>_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ produces the same choice function on the choice problems. Call this choice function $\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}$. Starting with the $B$ where $x$ is chosen, note that $>_{1}^{\prime}$ filters anything but $x$ out. Thus $\boldsymbol{c}(B)=\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}(B)$ Going to the $B$ where $x$ is available, but not chosen. Say that $y$ is chosen here. Note that we can not have $x \succ_{1}^{\prime} y$ since in that case that $x$ is chosen over a pivot; that is $y \notin A$. Thus, neither of the changes we implemented has an effect on choice in this problems and thus $\boldsymbol{c}(B)=\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}(B)$. Lastly, consider $B$ where $x$ is not present. We have only made changes to $x$. Thus, it directly follows that $\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}(B)=\boldsymbol{c}(B)$. Therefore, $\left(>_{1}^{\prime},>_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ is a TRSM-rationalization of $(\mathcal{B}, \boldsymbol{c})$. Since $x=\operatorname{argmin} \succ_{2}^{\prime}$, it follows that no restriction is imposed on the lower contour set of $x$.

STC. For LA and LC, the we can directly conclude this from (1) and (2) and following our previous reasoning using the argument of De Clippel and Rozen (2021); that is, if $x$ is not present, it can not put new restrictions on the preference relation.

For RSM the result follows from Corollary 1 and the proof of Theorem 1 in Manzini and Mariotti (2007) where the authors show that given a incomplete data set one can construct $>_{2}$ in the following form:

$$
\succ_{1}=\{(x, y): x=\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y\}\}
$$

Now assume that there are no restriction on the lower-contour set of $x$ given the data set $\left(\mathcal{B}_{1}, \boldsymbol{c}_{1}\right)$. Hence, adding new data such as $\left(\mathcal{B}_{2}, \boldsymbol{c}_{2}\right)$ where $x$ is not available will not add any restrictions to enrich $>_{2}$. Thus the result follows.

For TRSM, first note that as argued in Horan (2016) the models where the second rationale is only transitive (that is the model in Horan (2016)) is both in terms of identification and axiomatization equivalent to TRSM. Furthermore, Theorem 3 in that paper establishes that $x \succ_{2} y$ if and only if there exists a 3 -cycle $x y z$ such that $\boldsymbol{c}\{x, y, z\} \neq z$. Thus adding data where $x$ is not available will not add to $>_{2}$.

abstract:
In a two-stage model of choice a decision maker first shortlists a given menu
and then applies her preferences. We show that a sizeable class of these models
run into significant issues in terms of identification of preferences
(welfare-relevance) and thus cannot be used for welfare analysis. We classify
these models by their revealed preference principles and expose the principle
that we deem to be the root of their identification issue. Taking our analysis
to an experimental data, we observe that half of the alternatives that are
revealed preferred to another under rational choice are left revealed preferred
to nothing for any member of this class of models. Furthermore, the
welfare-relevance of the specific models established in the literature are much
worse. The model with the highest welfare-relevance produces a revealed
preference relation with the average density of 2% (1 out of 45 possible
comparisons revealed), while rational choice does 63% (28 out of 45 possible
comparisons). We argue that the issue is not an inherent feature of two-stage
models, and rather lies in the approach with which the first stage is modelled
in the literature.
